review_title: One of my favorite places I've worked!
job_title: Instructor, Flight I in Warrensburg, MO
pros: I had great coworkers, and it really felt like a family, or a team pulling together.  Nice campus, and the airport is really growing (worked in the aviation department).  I loved the fact that several times a week, students and faculty would all go to lunch together.  It created a really great working atmosphere.  While the aviation department has seen a rough few years, it's really turning around lately, thanks to new leadership.
cons: The department chair and dean at the time were absolutely horrible, but hooray, they're gone now!  some of the airplane fleet were also dated.  Some of the airport flight operations supervisors also have negative opinions about flight instructors who did not train at UCM.

review_title: Dedicated professionals, good benefits, but out-of-touch administration that embraces style-over-substance management.
pros: If you're in a permanent position that gets them, the benefits are very good, including educational benefits (15 free credit hours/year and half-tuition waiver for family members) and generous leave policies. Work-life balance is generally good. While staffing is thin in many areas, most supervisors embrace the opportunities for professional development these circumstances encourage. Many faculty and staff are courteous and helpful, and truly dedicated to their work.
cons: Compensation is mediocre or poor at non-administrative levels. (Local cost-of-living is also low, but not low enough to make this a non-factor.) Advancement is very difficult beyond a certain point, making this more likely a stop-over point than a career destination for anyone under a certain age. For those who do want to stay, figure you'll mostly move up by changing departments. Many areas are very slow to embrace new ideas or change. Administration is focused heavily on enrollment growth to address budget shortfalls, with no apparent long-term strategy for managing the associated consequences.

review_title: Great benefits, not the best environment
pros: Benefits, location and size of the town, beautiful campus
cons: Staff culture and social judgement, expectations, not the best training (may vary by department, but I usually felt like everyone expected me to know everything about the school since most employees grew up in the area or graduated from there. I also had a few occasions where I was expected to know how to do something I had never done before)

job_title: Operations Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great Place to work. Excellent benefits
cons: There are no real cons.

pros: Friendly staff and students. Solid potential of creating harmonious environment given a true "servant leader" President who operate from integrity and selflessness.
cons: There is an inherent distrust and friction between the academics and the support staff. Current senior leadership is myopic to the ever-changing environment of competitiveness within higher education. Senior leadership abhors any notion that higher-education is indeed a competitive business. Needs to seriously expand online offerings and market to domestic students, vice going after foreign students. The senior university leadership is not unlike our country's current highest leader...long on rhetoric and "show"...in realty, operating out of self-interest and self-aggrandizement while lining up his next and better "gig".  Support staff are paid woefully bottom-basement wages while senior leadership feather-beds their own compensation. New senior staff are added as senior leadership sees fit...as are "consultants"...all the while failing to appropriately recognize and compensate longstanding, competent support staff...all the while stating money is in short supply.

job_title: Campus Visit Coordinator in Warrensburg, MO
pros: Everyone at the University is very understanding when implications arise concerning class and needing time off. When these occasions arise no one will ever tell you no. Great place to work when your schedule is demanding
cons: The pay is unbearable low and they only pay you what they have to - minimum wage. The work is also repetitive and it's work no one else wants to do.

pros: Working with great students is always a plus. We also have a very innovative President who has made great progress on campus and in the community.
cons: Some of the staff members are not receptive to change because they have worked here forever. Also, since we are a public University there haven't been many pay increases happening.

pros: Since all of the associates were students (one of the requirements), they were very flexible with your hours.  Management was really friendly as well.
cons: Pay was minimum wage, which isn't much for a college kid.  Seniority really took over on holidays, so there were times you wouldn't get to go home for a specific holiday, which is a lot for someone in college.

pros: Benefits are good and you get to go to school for free if you work there
cons: PAY IS horrible, they do not even compare to jobs in kansas city, however its to be expected in a small town where there are hardly no jobs.  communication is not all that great and unless you are a professer, there is a big turnover rate.  Once people find out how much more KC jobs pay, they leave

pros: Love the children I get to work with. It's great to be working on campus while I attend classes!
cons: Schedule changes every semester. Hours are capped at 25 hours per week due to funding issues and the university seems to ignore the center a lot.

review_title: Great People, good place for hard workers. I was lucky to get good package and great bosses!
pros:
My office and the people who ran it. They were really good. Smart, kind and they value their employees.
Office of Accessibility Services Rocks!!
cons: Its a comparatively small University 10,000 students.

pros: Cheap tuition. Nice environment. Helpful staffs.
cons:
The CyberSecurity program is substandard, taught by a Ph.D. who doesn’t have 1/2 a day working in a real-world experience. All their classes are just about one theory after another from text books and text books. All their so-called real labs are relying to NetLab+ where it provide virtual labs, and lab materials to their students. UCM just signed a contract with them.  As a result, UCM doesn’t even have a real class and labs for either Microsoft / Linux / Cisco let alone Security aspects on those subjects. They don’t even have a class to teach students how to perform vulnerability scanning, pen-test, web attack, how to monitor the network and how to prevent the network from being infected in the first place. They don’t even differentiate the difference in terms of importance between LAN and DMZ.

UCM is a nice institution and I hate to talk bad about them, but I just can’t ignore the problem that UCM is posing to their students, which is wasting their time and money for something that are totally out of date, having no real-world values at all and all talks.

There is no way their students - including the ones who could graduate at 4.0 average from their CyberSecurity program could get a job and/or getting a job but keeping it because they are armed with nothing.

It’s time to treat every single degree seriously or UCM should close their CyberSecurity program, immediately. 

No wonder why the companies, and a lot more institutions, keep getting hacked because the so-called Cyber Experts who have graduated  from a university like UCM are only armed themselves with one textbook after another.  

It’s sad that we have the means, but we have chosen to produce no more talk-the-talk like this every single year.  

I’d suggest UCM to hire a real pro on CyberSecurity to lead their program like UMUC (100% Program).
